instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .
definitions.P5VG3S_PGOOD: What is P5VG3S_PGOOD? P5VG3S_PGOOD is a signal that indicates that the PP5V_G3S power rail is functioning properly. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
This Mac was left in a humid and freezing environment overnight, and the next day it stopped working. 
There are no signs of corrosion or liquid damage.

When I plug in the charger, the voltage goes to 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a. 
After a few seconds, it drops to 0.03A, rises to 0.9A, and finally goes back to 0.07A, cycling repeatedly.

It's going to DFU and when I try to revive it gets stuck at the loading bar halfway through installing the system, forever and with no error message.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
SIG OUT / <SIGNAL>PMU_CLK32K_SOC</SIGNAL> 0.85V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R_PMUGPIO</SIGNAL> 1.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> 0.82V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3V - Cycling every 17 secs
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> 0.9V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> 1.1V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.75V - Cycling every 17 secs


<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.01V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 5.12V drops to 4.7V and back to 5.10V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> 3.31V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> 1.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 1.25V - Cycling every 17 secs

<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL> 1.8V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> 0.59V - Cycling every 17 secs
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> 2.52VCycling every 17 secs

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>=0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
Try connecting known good battery.

Just in case, do a SMC reset too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
Just tried another good battery and SMC reset and same issue. 
This is the message it gets if leave Apple Configurator trying after 20 minutes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
Flash SoC ROM and try again DFU.
Don't forget to make backup.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message: Do you have the firmware, please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
I'm using the TL866II Plus, but it doesn't have the profile for the IC AT25SF321, so I just remove the IC MX25U3235F from another logicboard that matches the schematics and flashed the firmware. Apple Cong. gives another error message and still not working.

Should I be looking at why  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
That chip is 1V8 compatible, not for 3V3.

What error do you get now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V, and the amps vary between 0.07a and 0.9a.
threads.message:
TL866II Plus automatically changes the voltage.

I forgot to take a picture of the error message.
I will flash it again.
